page_analysis.text_content:
Roofed porches on the 1st floor

How to determine if a porch is at least 50% open (using Fig 5 as an example)

Fig 5 Roofed 1st floor porch

Step 1: Determine the perimeter of the porch and divide it into
segments that will allow a comparison of closed and
open segments.

The perimeter of the porch in Fig 5 is shown below. It is the sum of
segments A throug G. It is 70 linear feet.

8

visual_elements.description: An isometric drawing of a house with a roofed porch on the first floor. The porch extends along the front and side of the house, supported by columns. The house has multiple windows and a pitched roof.

A top-down plan view of a porch, showing its perimeter divided into segments labeled A through F (G is mentioned in text but not explicitly labeled on the diagram). Dimensions are provided for several segments. The diagram shows the shape of the porch with an angled corner.

technical_specifications.parameter: Total perimeter of porch (A through G)

subheadings: How to determine if a porch is at least 50% open (using Fig 5 as an example)

additional_notes: Page number '8' is located at the bottom left.
A large grey rectangular block is present under the main heading, possibly a placeholder for an image or additional text that is not visible.
The text 'throug G' appears to be a typo and should likely be 'through G'.
